March 17

Harvesting data and testing election law

The Times reported that in 2014 contractors and employees of Cambridge Analytica, eager to sell psychological profiles of American voters to political campaigns, acquired the private Facebook data of tens of millions of users — the largest known leak in Facebook history.

In March, The New York Times, working with The Observer of London and The Guardian, obtained a cache of documents from inside Cambridge Analytica, the data firm principally owned by the right-wing donor Robert Mercer.
Our article first showed how Cambridge received warnings from its own lawyer, Laurence Levy, as it employed European and Canadian citizens on campaigns, potentially violating American election law.
The documents proved that the firm , where the former Trump aide Stephen K. Bannon was a board member, used data improperly obtained from Facebook to build voter profiles.
The news put Cambridge under investigation and thrust Facebook into its biggest crisis ever.
The Times also found that tranches of raw data still existed beyond Facebook’s control.
